Water Street Seafood Company owner wants to open fast-food restaurant on Southside
Brad Lomax is renovating a former McDonald's location on Holly Road near Everhart Road into Tailfins
By Fanny S. Chirinos Corpus Christi Caller Times Posted February 11, 2011 at 6:43 p.m. , updated February 11, 2011 at 8:16 p.m.
Discuss Print A A A
Tailfins Restaurant
See this entire gallery at full size
CORPUS CHRISTI — Brad Lomax has wanted to open a Southside restaurant for 28 years. He will in April.
The owner of several downtown businesses, Lomax is renovating a former McDonald's location on Holly Road near Everhart Road into Tailfins, a seafood eatery that will offer reasonably priced food options and a drive-thru.
A restaurant on the Southside, and one that caters to fast-food lovers are both firsts for Lomax, the owner of several businesses downtown, including four restaurants.
Lomax wanted to open his first restaurant along South Padre Island Drive in 1983, but had a hard time getting property owners to take a chance on a then-28-year-old, inexperienced entrepreneur, he said. So he took his vision downtown.
Now he wants to cater to the consumer who is watching his or her budget and not wanting to spend $15 on a meal.
"I want to work on recipes that bring our average cost down to reach a different market," said Lomax, who started building renovations earlier this month. "With the economy, people are looking at value plus savings. We're looking to put the value on the plate, not necessarily the ambiance. The place will be nice, but we're not winning awards for design."
That doesn't mean fans of his restaurant Water Street Seafood Company will go without. Lomax plans to keep staples such as his caldo xochitl, gumbo and walnut dressing.
His fish will be fresh, never frozen, he said. The menu, which still is still being put together, will contain a good mix of grilled and fried dishes such as fried shrimp baskets and grilled chicken or shrimp salads, he said.
Breaking from his business model, which has served him well, is not a big gamble, said Dee Haven, owner of Haven and Associates, a restaurant consulting firm.
"He's not giving up what's working for him well downtown," he said. "He's expanding into another part of town and modifying slightly what has been proven to work in Corpus Christi. I would guess most of his regular customers downtown live on the Southside. If he adheres to his reputation for quality, tasty food, he'll be just as successful."
